   - Patient was admitted, right central line was placed, arterial line
   was placed.
   - Patient was given 2 L NS (received 5 L at OSH), then 4 L of LR for
   CVP <14 and/or SBP <90.
   - Abdominal ultrasound completed, liver was without abnormalities. No
   intra or extra-hepatic duct dilatation, CBD 3 mm, gall bladder
   [** 420**] so could not be assessed for stones. Patent portal flow
   without occlusion.
   - Surgery [**Name (NI) 420**] given abdominal distension and bladder pressure of
   38, worsening respiratory status. Surgery following closely for
   possible laparotomy if needed to relieve abdominal compartment
   syndrome.
   - ERCP team [**Name (NI) 420**], case discussed, given improving amylase, lipase,
   and LFTs, and lack of stone in CBD, appears he passed stone so no ERCP
   at this time.
   - Trials of changing over to AC to increase rate unsuccessful overnight
   as patient
s PIP very high (50
s) and patient fighting ventilator.
   After patient on increased sedation and neo, was able to switch mode to

s to 80
   - Cardiology [**Name (NI) 420**] and reviewed EKG given ST elevations in inferior
   leads, rising troponins and already elevated CK
s. Cardiology felt

s. Decision not to
   anti-coagulate given risk of hemorrhagic pancreatitis.
   - Patient
s family called and updated this AM, will be in to visit.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, with hypotension, worsening
   renal function, and elevated cardiac enzymes overnight.
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated in setting of respiratory distress,
   also given need for aggressive IVF resuscitation. Did not tolerated
   several attempts at trials of AC, with PIP that were very high (>50),
   however this morning respiratory team was able to switch him over to
   AC. In setting of IVFs, needed to increase oxygen to 100% FiO2 from 70%
   to maintain oxygenation. Given that his acidosis is worsening
   (metabolic), would ideally like to go up on rate to help compensate
   further; this may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of
   paralytics. Increased abdominal pressure also is likely leading to
   higher pleural pressures, so additional data would be helpful.
   - Will place esophageal balloon to obtain data on pleural pressures,
   plateau pressures
   - Trending ABGs, CXR w/volume overload but no ARDS (will be mindful of
   potential of developing ARDS given severe pancreatitis)
   - Patient received levofloxacin for question of consolidation (versus
   atelectasis versus asp PNA) on CXR at OSH, also may have had
   aspiration, so will follow daily CXR
   - Will paralyze patient and see if able to better ventilate to improve
   oxygenation, BP, and pH
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post over 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - F/u final RUQ u/s
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - CRP pending
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, was
   slightly rising (2.6) but then trending downward. Also hyperglycemia,
   and was initially resuscitated with normal saline.
   - As noted above, attempting to change to AC and increase rate to help
   optimize pH by blowing off Co2
   - Trend ABGs, lactate, treat hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin. No recent steroid use to suspect
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Will likely add levophed if second pressor is needed.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echo cardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, HCT drop. At this time,
   risks outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern of
   hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but not very high)
   troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different
   from [**4-21**]), cardiology was [**Month/Year (2) 420**] and reviewed EKG and case, felt
   current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE could be
   ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change
   in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Will consider formal cardiology consult after echocardiogram is
   abnormal or should troponin markedly elevated.
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue baby ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today.
   # Hyperkalemia: Improved,  in the setting of ARF, responded to IVFs and
   bicarbonate. No EKG changes c/w hyperkalemia.
   - Consider insulin/glucose, kayexalate
   - Follow trend, monitoring on telemetry.
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has been
   1.7-1.9 here. FENa 0.21% suggestive of pre-renal etiology, likely
   secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, as well as
   abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also received dye with CT at
   OSH. Anticipate given low urine output, borderline hypotension, that
   patient also will have component of ATN.
   - aggressive IVF hydration
   - urine lytes
   - renally dose meds
   - consider renal consult
   - Mucomist
   # Abdominal distension: Concern is for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Continuing to monitor pressure, will see if paralytics improve
   bladder pressure. Should pressure rise >40, will need laparotory, which
   will be last resort.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition: NPO for now, nutrition consult for TPN
   Glycemic Control: Insulin drip

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease who presented with hypotension, bradycardia, and epigastric pain. He was found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and liver function tests, indicating acute pancreatitis. The patient was intubated due to respiratory distress and worsening renal function. He also has elevated cardiac enzymes, suggesting possible myocardial infarction.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is worsening, and he requires aggressive ventilatory support. There is a concern for the development of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) due to severe pancreatitis.
2. Abdominal compartment syndrome: The patient's distended abdomen and elevated bladder pressure indicate the possibility of abdominal compartment syndrome, which can compromise organ function.
3. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension is likely secondary to third spacing of fluids in the abdomen from pancreatitis and sepsis-related systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS).
4. Metabolic acidosis: The patient has a worsening metabolic acidosis, possibly due to lactic acidosis in the setting of renal failure.
5. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe acute pancreatitis, likely caused by gallstones. This condition carries a risk of complications such as infected pancreatic necrosis or abscess formation.
6. Cardiac issues: The patient's EKG changes and elevated cardiac enzymes raise concerns for myocardial infar

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement, but improved abdominal
   pressures after paralyzed.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Initially did not tolerated AC, but
   necessary to switch over to AC given metabolic acidosis. Yesterday
   paralytics were initiated to attempt to lessen work of breathing and
   allow for synchrony on ventilator so patient could tolerate AC mode.
   This was successful, and esophageal balloon helped further titrate
   PEEP. Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis
   and possible aspiration.
   - Will aim to stop paralytics today to lessen risk of myopathy and
   follow ABG
s to see if this is tolerated
   - Will aim to lower tidal volumes to reach lower volumes closer to ARDS
   net protocol (rate and tidal volumes were increased to rise minute
   ventilation to help with metabolic acidosis)
   - Continue antibiotics as noted below.
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   #  Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, and
   now trending downward. Working on treating hyperglycemia as well.
   - Will consult renal for further assistance managing acid base status,
   as appears patient likely will not need CVVH, but wish to have them
   aware and following in event this acidosis worsens or cannot improve
   with changing ventilator settings. Appreciate assistance
   - Will follow ABGs, weigh benefits lowering tidal volumes (and going up
   on rate) to help ARDS versus improving acidosis, consider bicarbonate
   supplementation
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed, given
   LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes improving, no role at present, but will
   have low threshold to consider should status worsen
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present (no necrosis seen on CT)
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin (but more likely cardiac enzyme leak
   from stress in setting of SIRS and hypotension, no EKG changes). No
   recent steroid use to suspect adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echocardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   - Weaning pressors as tolerated (does of neo has lessened)
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, blood pressure drop. At
   this time, risks continue to outweigh benefits for anticoagulation
   given concern of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but
   not very high) troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not
   markedly different from [**4-21**]), cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed
   EKG and case, felt current EKG was not significantly different from
   old, STE could be ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other
   recommendations for change in management, as management of his
   pancreatitis was felt to be larger priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today, will follow up results
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has risen
   to over 3.0. FENa 0.21% suggestive of pre-renal etiology, likely
   secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, also with
   possible component of abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also
   received dye with CT at OSH. Urine output has picked up today with
   100-150 today (as opposed to 10-20 cc/hr initially)
   Picture supports that of ATN secondary to hypotension, with possible
   dye nephropathy as well. Hopefull that he will be able to avoid
   dialysis given what appears to be post-ATN diuresis, but will obtain
   renal consult to help manage him in event that his volume status,
   hyperkalemia, and/or acidosis become difficult to manage. Appreciate
   assistance.
   - Supportive care as noted above, continuing to treat hyperkalemia (on
   insulin gtt), acidosis, monitoring urine output
   # Abdominal distension: Concern was for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance. Bladder pressures are currently
   in teens now.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   # Leukocytosis: New WBC to 13.5, differential from [**11-9**] with 7 bands.
   No overwhelming evidence of infection, but has had low grade
   temperatures. Must consider infection of necrotic pancreas, but no
   intervention at this time given he is already on appropriate antibiotic
   coverage and has only had low grade temperatures, and pressor
   requirement is lessening.
   -          F/u final CXR read
   -          F/u cx data
   -          Cont antibiotics as noted above.
   -          Hold on repeat imaging of abd (would need contrast to fully
   evaluate), but if status dramatically worsens, would consider CT guided
   biopsy of pancreatis

Summary:
The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status post CABG, who presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and liver function tests (LFTs). He is intubated for respiratory distress and requires aggressive intravenous fluid resuscitation. The patient has been diagnosed with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), severe acute pancreatitis, and possible aspiration.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be secondary to significant third spacing of fluids in the abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia. There is also a possibility of septic shock due to infection.
2. Acute Kidney Injury (AKI): The patient's elevated creatinine levels suggest acute kidney injury, possibly due to hypotension, third spacing of fluids, or dye nephropathy from contrast exposure during imaging.
3. Arrhythmias: The patient has shown new EKG changes, including TWI in V1 and V2 with <1 mm STE in inferior leads. These changes could indicate myocardial ischemia or injury, possibly related to the patient's recent CABG surgery or ongoing hypotension.
4. Abdominal Compartment Syndrome: The patient's distended abdomen and elevated bladder pressures suggest the possibility of abdominal compartment syndrome, which can lead to organ dysfunction if not managed promptly.
5. Infection: Despite appropriate

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   intubated for increased work of breathing, with hypotension, worsening
   renal function, and elevated cardiac enzymes overnight.
   # Respiratory failure: Intubated in setting of respiratory distress,
   also given need for aggressive IVF resuscitation. Did not tolerated
   several attempts at trials of AC, with PIP that were very high (>50),
   however this morning respiratory team was able to switch him over to
   AC. In setting of IVFs, needed to increase oxygen to 100% FiO2 from 70%
   to maintain oxygenation. Given that his acidosis is worsening
   (metabolic), would ideally like to go up on rate to help compensate
   further; this may require additional sedation and possibly a trial of
   paralytics. Increased abdominal pressure also is likely leading to
   higher pleural pressures, so additional data would be helpful.
   ARDS net protocol for ARDS
   - Will place esophageal balloon to obtain data on pleural pressures,
   plateau pressures
   - Trending ABGs, CXR w/volume overload but no ARDS (will be mindful of
   potential of developing ARDS given severe pancreatitis)
   - Patient received levofloxacin for question of consolidation (versus
   atelectasis versus asp PNA) on CXR at OSH, also may have had
   aspiration, so will follow daily CXR
   - Will paralyze patient and see if able to better ventilate to improve
   oxygenation, BP, and pH
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   - Patient is status-post over 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - F/u final RUQ u/s
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - CRP pending
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   ? d/c abx
   # Metabolic acidosis: In setting of ARF, lactate has been stable, was
   slightly rising (2.6) but then trending downward. Also hyperglycemia,
   and was initially resuscitated with normal saline.
   - As noted above, attempting to change to AC and increase rate to help
   optimize pH by blowing off Co2
   - Trend ABGs, lactate, treat hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin. No recent steroid use to suspect
   adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echo cardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   # EKG changes: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of
   STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. However, TWI
   are new. Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB
   fraction negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG and new TWI are
   in the setting of intravascular hypovolemia, HCT drop. At this time,
   risks outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern of
   hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising (but not very high)
   troponin levels, and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different
   from [**4-21**]), cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt
   current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE could be
   ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change
   in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes
   - Serial EKGs
   - Will consider formal cardiology consult after echocardiogram is
   abnormal or should troponin markedly elevated.
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue baby ASA
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated, start esmolol
   gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today.
   # Hyperkalemia: Improved,  in the setting of ARF, responded to IVFs and
   bicarbonate. No EKG changes c/w hyperkalemia.
   - Consider insulin/glucose, kayexalate
   - Follow trend, monitoring on telemetry.
   # ARF: Patient
s creatinine at presentation to OSH was 2.1, has been
   1.7-1.9 here. FENa 0.21% suggestive of pre-renal etiology, likely
   secondary to severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia, as well as
   abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also received dye with CT at
   OSH. Anticipate given low urine output, borderline hypotension, that
   patient also will have component of ATN.
   ? Renal c/s
   - aggressive IVF hydration
   - urine lytes
   - renally dose meds
   - consider renal consult
   - Mucomist
   # Abdominal distension: Concern is for compartment syndrome in setting
   of elevated bladder pressure, distended abdomen, third spacing of
   fluids. Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Continuing to monitor pressure, will see if paralytics improve
   bladder pressure. Should pressure rise >40, will need laparotory, which
   will be last resort.
   - Following trend of lactate, no evidence to suggest ischemic bowel or
   obstruction on imaging, no free air on CXR. SMA and aorta were free of
   significant atherosclerosis on CT.
   # Leukocytosis: New WBC to 13.5, differential from [**11-9**] with 7 bands.
   No overwhelming evidence of infection, but has had low grade
   temperatures
   -          F/u final CXR read
   -          F/u cx data
   -          Cont abx

He presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, and elevated pancreatic enzymes and liver function tests. The patient has been intubated for respiratory distress and worsening renal function, along with elevated cardiac enzymes.

The potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and there is a risk of further deterioration. The need for aggressive ventilation and potential paralysis may be necessary to improve oxygenation and blood pressure.

2. Acute kidney injury (AKI): The patient's renal function is compromised, as indicated by elevated creatinine levels and low urine output. There is a risk of developing or worsening AKI due to factors such as severe third spacing of fluids, relative hypovolemia, abdominal compartment syndrome, and potential acute tubular necrosis.

3. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe acute pancreatitis, likely secondary to gallstones. Complications related to pancreatitis, such as systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), necrosis, infection, or abscess formation, should be closely monitored.

4. Cardiac issues: The patient's history of coronary artery disease, previous CABG surgery, and EKG changes raise concerns about potential cardiac complications, including myocardial infarction or ventricular aneurysm.

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis, hypoxemic respiratory failure, NSTEMI, and non-oliguric acute renal failure. He presented with hypotension and has been in the ICU. The patient's condition has been complicated by abdominal compartment syndrome and persistent hypoxemia. He has been on various medications including vasopressin, phenylephrine, midazolam, cisatracurium, insulin, and fentanyl.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Abdominal compartment syndrome: This is a condition characterized by increased pressure within the abdomen, which can compromise organ function and blood flow. The patient's slightly distended and firm abdomen suggests the presence of abdominal compartment syndrome.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's hypoxemic respiratory failure indicates difficulty in oxygenating the blood. The crackles and rhonchi heard on chest examination may indicate pulmonary edema or pneumonia.

3. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's elevated creatinine levels and low urine output suggest acute renal failure. The differential diagnosis includes acute tubular necrosis (ATN), contrast nephropathy, or abdominal compartment syndrome as potential causes.

4. Cardiomyopathy: The decrease in ejection fraction (EF) seen on the preliminary read of the transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) raises concern for a primary cardiac event or sepsis-associated cardiomyopathy. Further

The patient's lab results indicate an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated blood glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests. The imaging shows bibasilar airspace opacity.

The assessment and plan for the patient include severe pancreatitis possibly caused by hypoxemic respiratory failure, NSTEMI, and non-oliguric ARF.    Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement, but improved abdominal
   pressures after paralyzed.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration. Overnight with desaturation while bathing, but now
   Fi02 back down to 80%, have successfully weaned TV
s to 550 with
   improved pH.
   - Will continue current settings, weaning FiO2 if possible, using lower
   tidal volumes to reach lower volumes closer to ARDS net protocol (rate
   and tidal volumes were increased to rise minute ventilation to help
   with metabolic acidosis)
   - Continue antibiotics as noted below.
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   #  Metabolic acidosis: Improving as renal function improves and
   ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly secondary to
   acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   Abdominal exam overall unchanged today.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed, given
   LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes improving, no role at present, but will
   have low threshold to consider should status worsen
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present (no necrosis seen on CT)
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome, and now in setting of fevers.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin (but more likely cardiac enzyme leak
   from stress in setting of SIRS and hypotension, no EKG changes). No
   recent steroid use to suspect adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echocardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   - Weaning pressors as tolerated (does of neo has lessened)
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2,
   with <1 mm of STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**].
   Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB fraction
   negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time,
   risks continue to outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern
   of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising troponin levels,
   and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different from [**4-21**]),
   cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt current EKG
   was not significantly different from old, STE could be ventricular
   aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change in
   management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes (will likely remain elevated in setting of
   his renal failure as will be slow to clear)
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA (PR while NG tube is to suction)
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated once off
   pressors, start esmolol gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed function
   noted could be in setting of SIRS
   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary to
   severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia causing hypotension, also
   with possible component of abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also
   received dye with CT at OSH so contrast nephropathy also a possibility.
   Urine output has picked up today with 100-150 today (as opposed to
   10-20 cc/hr initially)
   - Hopefull that he will be able to avoid dialysis given what appears to
   be post-ATN diuresis, but obtained renal consult to help manage him in
   event that his volume status, hyperkalemia, and/or acidosis become
   difficult to manage. Appreciate assistance.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 68-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease and previous CABG surgery. He presents with hypotension, bradycardia, epigastric pain, elevated pancreatic enzymes, and liver function tests (LFTs), indicating acute pancreatitis. The patient has been intubated due to respiratory failure, specifically hypoxemic respiratory failure and ARDS. He is on aggressive IV fluid resuscitation and pressors.

The patient's current conditions include:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient meets ARDS criteria, and his FiO2 is being weaned as tolerated.
2. Metabolic Acidosis: Improving with renal function improvement and optimized ventilatory settings. Bicarbonate drip may be considered if acidosis worsens.
3. Pancreatitis: Severe acute pancreatitis, most likely due to gallstones seen on CT. No history of alcohol use or elevated triglycerides.
4. Hypotension: Secondary to significant third spacing of fluids in the abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia. SIRS from pancreatitis is also a possibility.
5. EKG Changes: New TWI in V1, V2 with less than 1 mm STE in inferior leads. Initial CK was elevated, but troponin and MB fraction were negative.
6. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary

   Patient is a 68 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found to have elevated pancreatic enzymes and LFTs,
   with ARDS and persistent pressor requirement, but improved abdominal
   pressures after paralyzed.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration. Overnight with desaturation while bathing, but now
   Fi02 back down to 80%, have successfully weaned TV
s to 550 with
   improved pH.
   - Will continue current settings, weaning FiO2 if possible, using lower
   tidal volumes to reach lower volumes closer to ARDS net protocol (rate
   and tidal volumes were increased to rise minute ventilation to help
   with metabolic acidosis)
   - Continue antibiotics as noted below.
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   #  Metabolic acidosis: Improving as renal function improves and
   ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly secondary to
   acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFTs and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance.
   Abdominal exam overall unchanged today.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
based on discussion with
   ICU and surgical team, will hold on further IVF resuscitation as
   additional IVFs will further compromise respiratory status and have
   potential of significantly worsening abdominal compartment syndrome and
   necessitating laparotomy.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time
   - Hold off on ERCP consulted, given it appears stone has passed, given
   LFTs and pancreatitic enzymes improving, no role at present, but will
   have low threshold to consider should status worsen
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   acuity of patient
s illness, however no evidence of infection at
   present (no necrosis seen on CT)
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, lactate (lactate
   currently coming down, calcium stabilized after repleted)
   - Triglycerides pending
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance following abdominal for compartment
   syndrome, and now in setting of fevers.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Most likely secondary to significant third spacing of
   fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as
   SIRS from his pancreatitis. Do not suspect infection or sepsis, however
   cultures are pending. Also have to consider MI as possibility given EKG
   changes and elevated CK/Troponin (but more likely cardiac enzyme leak
   from stress in setting of SIRS and hypotension, no EKG changes). No
   recent steroid use to suspect adrenal insufficiency.
   - Cont neo, holding on further IVFs as noted above given concerns of
   worsening abd compartment syn and pulmonary edema. (CVP had been >14).
   Vasopressin added yesterday given low SBP.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above, cardiac echocardiogram
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending.
   - Weaning pressors as tolerated (does of neo has lessened)
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2,
   with <1 mm of STE in inferior leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**].
   Initial CK at OSH was elevated, with flat troponin and MB fraction
   negative. Patient does have h/o recent 4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time,
   risks continue to outweigh benefits for anticoagulation given concern
   of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis. Given rising troponin levels,
   and appearance of EKG (although not markedly different from [**4-21**]),
   cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] and reviewed EKG and case, felt current EKG
   was not significantly different from old, STE could be ventricular
   aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for change in
   management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be larger
   priority.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes (will likely remain elevated in setting of
   his renal failure as will be slow to clear)
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA (PR while NG tube is to suction)
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated once off
   pressors, start esmolol gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed function
   noted could be in setting of SIRS
   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary to

   transthoracic echo (likely from ARDS and positive-pressure ventilation,
   and catecholamines from ARDS/pancreatitis), any movement will decrease
   pre-load/venous return leading to hypotension with preferential
   vasocontrction and resultant transient hypoxia.

 per wife), around 450 cc, will increase respiratory rate as

   improves and ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly
   secondary to acute renal failure.

   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFT
s and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance. No
   change in abdominal examination.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
had held off on further
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension given concerns about oxygenation
   and worsening of abdominal compartment syndrome in setting of poor
   urine output. Given that his bladder pressure is now 9 and he has
   significant (likely post-ATN) auto-diuresis, will aim to wean pressors
   and bolus with fluids as long as respiratory status is stable.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time, as this would
   have risk of further dye exposure in setting of resolving ARF, and
   already on appropriate antibiotics (and HD stable, so surgical

   - ERCP team aware of patients.

   - Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Decreasing pressor requirement is encouraging.
   Hypotension with movement as noted above likely secondary to decreased
   venous return and forward flow with movement. Overall hypotension most
   likely secondary to significant third spacing of fluids in abdomen from
   pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as SIRS from his
   pancreatitis. No new clear wall motion abnormalities on transthoracic
   echocardiogram. Also in setting of post-ATN diuresis and new diarrhea

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease who presented with hypotension, bradycardia, and epigastric pain. He was found to have severe pancreatitis with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and persistent pressor requirement. The patient has been intubated and is receiving mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved with FiO2 weaning down to 80% and tidal volume reduction to 550 mL. The patient also has a history of gallstone pancreatitis and has undergone ERCP. He has persistent fevers, leukocytosis, and diarrhea. His renal function is improving, and he is producing urine. The patient's blood cultures show no growth, while sputum culture shows sparse growth of gram-negative rods. The echocardiogram shows mild symmetric left ventricular hypertrophy with normal cavity size and depressed right ventricular contractility. There is no evidence of pericardial effusion or valvular abnormality. The patient's acid-base status has improved, and his lactate levels are normal. He is receiving broad-spectrum antibiotics for suspected infection. The patient's condition remains stable, and he is expected to continue receiving ICU level of care. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has ARDS and is on mechanical ventilation. Weaning off the ventilator will be crucial to prevent further respiratory complications.
2. Infection: The patient has persistent

The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 102.0 degrees Fahrenheit, heart rate of 93 beats per minute, blood pressure of 89/63 mmHg, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 91%. The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume set at 550 mL, respiratory rate set at 28, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) at 12 cmH2O, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) at 80%, and plateau pressure at 25 cmH2O.

The patient has several medical interventions, including vasopressin infusion at 2.4 units/hour, phenylephrine infusion at 2 mcg/kg/min, midazolam (versed) infusion at 10 mg/hour, and fentanyl infusion at 250 mcg/hour. The patient is also receiving pantoprazole (protonix), heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and other medications as per the treatment plan.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 13.5 K/uL, slightly decreased hematocrit (Hct) of 36.5, normal platelet count (Plt) of 150 K/uL, elevated creatinine (Cr) of 3.1, and elevated troponin T of 0.94. Other lab values such as blood glucose, liver enzymes (ALT/AST), electrolytes (Na+/K+/Cl-), and kidney function tests are within normal limits.

Imaging studies reveal a dilated left atrium (LA) and right ventricular (RV) dilation with depressed systolic function on trans-thoracic echo. There are no significant valvular abnormalities noted.

The patient's assessment includes severe pancreatitis, MODS, renal function improvement, fever, and concern for progressive pancreatitis, necrosis, and infection. The plan is to continue vancomycin, flagyl, and re-evaluate the need for flagyl pending Clostridium difficile assay. Further plans will be determined based on the resident's note.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:

1. Infection: The patient's fever and elevated WBC count raise concerns for infection, especially considering his severe pancreatitis and MODS. Monitoring for signs of infection and appropriate antibiotic therapy should be continued.

2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status remains critical, with low oxygen saturation and high plateau pressures indicating potential lung injury. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters and adjustment of ventilator settings are necessary to ensure adequate oxygenation and ventilation.

The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis and multiorgan dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He is currently in the ICU and has been experiencing hypotension. The patient has shown signs of infection, including fever and positive cultures for gram-negative rods (GNR) in the sputum and urine. He has been receiving multiple antibiotics, including vancomycin, meropenem, and metronidazole. The patient's vital signs are unstable, with low blood pressure, high heart rate, and low oxygen saturation. He is sedated and intubated on mechanical ventilation with PRVC/AC mode. The respiratory support parameters indicate a high peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) and plateau pressure (Plateau). The patient has pitting edema in his extremities. Lab results show elevated white blood cell count, creatinine, and lactate levels, along with low platelet count and albumin. Imaging reveals dilated left atrium and right ventricular dilation with depressed systolic function, but no significant valvular abnormality. The patient's renal function is improving. The assessment is that the patient has severe pancreatitis, MODS, and possible infection. The plan includes continuing current antibiotics, weaning FiO2 when PaO2 is greater than 60, decreasing tidal volume to 6cc/kg, and further plans as per resident note.    Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 63 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found severe pancreatitis with ARDS and persistent
   pressor requirement, with improved respiratory status,  and renal
   function today, able to come off pressors.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration.. Suspect that in setting of RV dysfunction noted
   on transthoracic echo (likely from ARDS and positive-pressure
   ventilation, and catecholamines from ARDS/pancreatitis), any movement
   will decrease pre-load/venous return leading to hypotension with
   preferential vasocontrction and resultant transient hypoxia.
   - At goal 6cc/kg ARDSnet ventilation protocol, continue current TV and
   rate settings, will aim to wean FiO2 down to 40%, then consider weaning
   down PEEP.
   - Later today, if off pressors for >12 hrs and stable, will diuresis
   down to CVP <5 to help fluid status
   - Continue vancomycin and meropenem, adding 2^nd [**Doctor Last Name **] to cover gram
   negative rods for question of possible VAP or resistance organisms
   (stopped flagyl as  c. difficile negative)
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed
did not tolerate attempts
   to wean sedation overnight as was overbreathing vent and appeared
   uncomfortable.
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Much improved overnight as renal function
   improves and ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly
   secondary to acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFT
s and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance. No
   change in abdominal examination.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
had held off on further
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension given concerns about oxygenation
   and worsening of abdominal compartment syndrome in setting of poor
   urine output. Given that his bladder pressure remains relatively low
   (11, as compared to 30
s) and he has significant (likely post-ATN)
   auto-diuresis, will aim to wean pressors and bolus with fluids as long
   as respiratory status is stable.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time, as this would
   have risk of further dye exposure in setting of resolving ARF, and
   already on appropriate antibiotics (and HD stable, so surgical
   intervention not desired)
   - ERCP team aware of patients.
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam (day 1=[**11-10**]), started
   cipro yesterday.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, (lactate has been
   normal)
   - Triglycerides were within normal limits
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Now off pressors! Hypotension with movement as noted
   above likely secondary to decreased venous return and forward flow with
   movement. Overall hypotension most likely secondary to significant
   third spacing of fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to
   hypovolemia, as well as SIRS from his pancreatitis. No new clear wall
   motion abnormalities on transthoracic echocardiogram. Also in setting
   of post-ATN diuresis and new diarrhea and fevers with insensible
   losses. Do not suspect sepsis from infection as pressor need
   decreasing.
   - Will bolus with IVF if needed in lieu of re-starting pressors.
   - Cardiac enzymes have peaked, no need to continue following unless
   suspect new event
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending, as noted above.
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Do not suspect new ischemic event, but
   instead some low levels of demand ischemia secondary to hypotension and
   stress of infection/SIRS/pancreatitis with circulating catecholamies.
   Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of STE in inferior
   leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. Patient does have h/o recent
   4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time, risks continue to outweigh benefits for
   anticoagulation given concern of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis.
   Cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] morning after admission and reviewed EKG and
   case, felt current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE
   could be ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for
   change in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be
   larger priority.
   - CE trending downward
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA (PR if possible, currently with diarrhea, while NG tube
   is to suction)
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated once off
   pressors, start esmolol gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed RV
   function noted could be in setting of ARDS
   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.6 today. Suspected ATN secondary to
   severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia causing hypotension, also
   with possible component of abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also
   received dye with CT at OSH so contrast nephropathy also a possibility.
   Urine output has picked up today, as opposed to 10-20 cc/hr initially.
   # Leukocytosis: Improved WBC today and decreasing fever curve. Diarrhea
   two nights ago. Must consider infection of necrotic pancreas, but no
   intervention at this time given he is already on appropriate antibiotic
   coverage and has only had low grade temperatures, and pressor
   requirement is lessening, and no necrosis seen on CT of abdomen.
   -          Follow up on culture data, added 2nd [**Doctor Last Name **] for gram
   negatives given GNRs in sputum and fevers
   -          Cont antibiotics as noted above, stopped flagyl if c.
   difficile toxin negative.
   -          Hold on repeat imaging of abd (would need contrast to fully
   evaluate), but if status dramatically worsens, would consider CT guided
   biopsy of pancreatis
   -          Appreciate surgical assistance.
   .

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 63 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found severe pancreatitis with ARDS and persistent
   pressor requirement, with improved respiratory status, acidosis, and
   renal function today.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration. Overnight with desaturation while bathing, but now
   Fi02 back down to 80%, have successfully weaned TV
s to 550 with
   improved pH. Suspect that in setting of RV dysfunction noted on
   transthoracic echo (likely from ARDS and positive-pressure ventilation,
   and catecholamines from ARDS/pancreatitis), any movement will decrease
   pre-load/venous return leading to hypotension with preferential
   vasocontrction and resultant transient hypoxia.
   - Continue to decrease TV to meet ARDS net goal of 6 cc/kg (height is
   5
 per wife), around 450 cc, will increase respiratory rate as
   needed should pH worsen, goal pH >7.20
   - Wean FiO2 as tolerated for goal pO2 >60
   - Continue vancomycin and meropenem for empiric coverage, will consider
   additional of 2^nd [**Doctor Last Name **] to cover gram negative rods in sputum. If c.
   difficile negative, will stop flagyl as it provides redundant coverage
   (already on meropenem)
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed.
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Much improved overnight as renal function
   improves and ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly
   secondary to acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFT
s and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance. No
   change in abdominal examination.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
had held off on further
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension given concerns about oxygenation
   and worsening of abdominal compartment syndrome in setting of poor
   urine output. Given that his bladder pressure is now 9 and he has
   significant (likely post-ATN) auto-diuresis, will aim to wean pressors
   and bolus with fluids as long as respiratory status is stable.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time, as this would
   have risk of further dye exposure in setting of resolving ARF, and
   already on appropriate antibiotics (and HD stable, so surgical
   intervention not desired)
   - ERCP team aware of patients.
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam/flagyl(day 1=[**11-10**]), given
   persistent fevers to 102, will continue antibiotics, but will stop
   flagyl if c. difficile negative. If continues to [**Last Name (LF) 1694**], [**First Name3 (LF) 178**] consider
   additional double gram negative coverage.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, (lactate has been
   normal)
   - Triglycerides were within normal limits
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Decreasing pressor requirement is encouraging.
   Hypotension with movement as noted above likely secondary to decreased
   venous return and forward flow with movement. Overall hypotension most
   likely secondary to significant third spacing of fluids in abdomen from
   pancreatitis, leading to hypovolemia, as well as SIRS from his
   pancreatitis. No new clear wall motion abnormalities on transthoracic
   echocardiogram. Also in setting of post-ATN diuresis and new diarrhea
   and fevers with insensible losses. Do not suspect sepsis from infection
   as pressor need decreasing.
   - Cont neo (did not tolerate trial of levophed which caused
   tachycardia), wean as tolerated. If oxygenation is stable with new vent
   settings, will aim to further wean pressors and bolus instead given
   that CVP is down and patient has had significant diuresis and losses as
   noted above.
   - Following cardiac enzymes as noted above (just for purposes of noting
   peak)
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending, as noted above.
   # EKG changes, history of CAD: Do not suspect new ischemic event, but
   instead some low levels of demand ischemia secondary to hypotension and
   stress of infection/SIRS/pancreatitis with circulating catecholamies.
   Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of STE in inferior
   leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. Patient does have h/o recent
   4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time, risks continue to outweigh benefits for
   anticoagulation given concern of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis.
   Cardiology was contact[**Name (NI) **] morning after admission and reviewed EKG and
   case, felt current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE
   could be ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for
   change in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be
   larger priority.
   Will continue to trend enzymes, which remain difficult to interpret in
   setting of renal insufficiency.  Do not suspect ARDS, and not a
   candidate for other interventions or management at present.
   - Continue to cycle enzymes (will likely remain elevated in setting of
   his renal failure as will be slow to clear)
   - Holding statin in the setting of elevated LFTs
   - Continue ASA (PR if possible, currently with diarrhea, while NG tube
   is to suction)
   - Transfuse for HCT goal >25
   - Hold BB in the setting of hypotension, if tolerated once off
   pressors, start esmolol gtt
   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed RV
   function noted could be in setting of ARDS
   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.9 today. Suspected ATN secondary to
   severe third spacing and relative hypovolemia causing hypotension, also
   with possible component of abdominal compartment syndrome. Patient also
   received dye with CT at OSH so contrast nephropathy also a possibility.
   Urine output has picked up today with 90cc/hr today (as opposed to
   10-20 cc/hr initially)
   - Hopefull that he will be able to avoid dialysis given what appears to
   be post-ATN diuresis, but obtained renal consult to help manage him in
   event that his volume status, hyperkalemia, and/or acidosis become
   difficult to manage. Appreciate assistance.
   - Supportive care as noted above, continuing to treat hyperkalemia (on
   insulin gtt), acidosis, monitoring urine output (no phos in TPN)
   # Abdominal distension: Much improved, bladder pressure now 9.
   # Leukocytosis: Stable WBC to 13.5 today. Diarrhea overnight. Continues
   to have temperatures, overnight to 102. Must consider infection of
   necrotic pancreas, but no intervention at this time given he is already
   on appropriate antibiotic coverage and has only had low grade
   temperatures, and pressor requirement is lessening, and no necrosis
   seen on CT of abdomen.
   -          Follow up on culture data, added 2nd [**Doctor Last Name **] for gram
   negatives if continues to [**Doctor Last Name 1694**] based on respiratory culture
   -          Cont antibiotics as noted above, will stop flagyl if c.
   difficile toxin negative.
   -          Hold on repeat imaging of abd (would need contrast to fully
   evaluate), but if status dramatically worsens, would consider CT guided
   biopsy of pancreatis
   -          Appreciate surgical assistance.
   .
   # Hypernatremia: Suspect secondary to insensible fluid losses,
   significant diuresis.
           - D5W at 100cc/hr, follow up PM sodium

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is currently in the ICU and has been experiencing several medical complications. Here is a summary of the information and potential medical complications:

- The patient's tidal volume has decreased to 450 cc, and their respiratory rate has increased to 32 breaths per minute. The fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) has been decreased to 60%.
- The patient was weaned off neo (likely referring to neomycin) and received 2 L boluses of lactated Ringer's (LR) solution for a low systolic blood pressure (SBP) of less than 90 mmHg.
- The patient was previously on Flagyl, but it was stopped after testing negative for Clostridium difficile toxin.
- Ciprofloxacin was added for double gram-negative coverage due to persistent fevers.
- The patient's repeat sodium levels are trending down.
- The patient experienced a spike in fever to 102 degrees Fahrenheit in the afternoon and 101.5 degrees Fahrenheit overnight, with cultures being obtained.
- The patient has no known drug allergies.
- The last doses of antibiotics administered were metronidazole on 11/12/2182 at 08:00 AM, vancomycin on 11/12/2182 at 10:00 AM, ciprofloxacin on 11/12/2182 at 08:40 PM, and meropenem on 11/13/218

- Infusions: Vasopressin - 1.2 units/hour, Fentanyl - 250 mcg/hour, Insulin - Regular - 8 units/hour, Midazolam (Versed) - 8 mg/hour.
- Other ICU medications: Pantoprazole (Protonix) on 11/12/2182 at 08:30 AM, Heparin Sodium (Prophylaxis) on 11/13/2182 at 12:41 AM.
- Other medications: Aspirin 300 mg PR, Chlorhexidine rinse, Albuterol and atrovent inhalers, Heparin SQ TID, Pantoprazole 40 mg.
- Review of systems is unchanged from admission except as noted below.

- Flowsheet data as of 11/13/2182 07:36 AM includes vital signs, hemodynamic monitoring, fluid balance, respiratory support, physical examination, labs/radiology, and imaging data.
- Labs show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low platelet count, elevated creatinine, troponin-T within normal range, elevated lipase, and abnormal liver function tests.
- Microbiology data shows C. difficile toxin negative, with all other cultures negative except for sputum culture with gram-negative rods on 11/10.
- Imaging data includes pending chest X-ray.
- Assessment and plan include ICU care, nutrition, glycemic control, lines, prophylaxis, and comments about family meeting and code status.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory complications due to decreased tidal volume and Fi02, which may lead to further respiratory distress or failure.
2. Infection or sepsis due to persistent fevers, despite antibiotic treatment, which could be indicated by the elevated white blood cell count and positive gram-negative rods in the sputum culture.
3. Organ dysfunction or failure, such as acute kidney injury indicated by elevated creatinine and low urine output, or hepatic dysfunction indicated by abnormal liver function tests.
4. Hemodynamic instability indicated by low blood pressure and high vasopressin requirement.
5. Potential complications related to prolonged mechanical ventilation and intensive care unit stay, such as ventilator-associated pneumonia or delirium.

Summary:
The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS). He is currently off pressors with normalizing renal function. The patient continues on low tidal volume ventilation and his FiO2 is being weaned as tolerated for PaO2 > 60. When FiO2 < 0.4, PEEP will be weaned. If stable off pressors for 12 hours, diuresis will be attempted. The patient is on vancomycin and ciprofloxacin pending specification of sputum culture. Suspected fever to ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) but pancreatic necrosis is also a possibility. Troponin peaked and no longer needs to be followed. Further plans are as per the resident's note.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has a fever and bibasilar infiltrates on imaging, which raises suspicion for VAP. It is important to continue with appropriate antibiotic therapy and maintain proper lung hygiene.
2. Pancreatic necrosis: Given the patient's severe pancreatitis, there is a possibility of pancreatic necrosis. Monitoring for signs of worsening abdominal pain, leukocytosis, and changes in vital signs is crucial.
3. Renal dysfunction: Although the patient's renal function is normalizing, it is important to monitor kidney function closely and adjust fluids and medications accordingly to prevent renal complications.
4. Cardiovascular instability:

Summary: The patient is a 63-year-old man with severe pancreatitis and multiple organ dysfunction syndrome (MODS), including acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). He is currently off pressors with improving renal function. He continues on low tidal volume (Vt)/high positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) ventilation and is being weaned off fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) as tolerated, aiming for a PaO2 > 60. Once FiO2 is at 0.4, the plan is to wean PEEP. Diuretics will be attempted if the patient is stable off pressors for 12 hours. The patient is currently on vancomycin and ciprofloxacin pending the speciation of sputum culture, suspecting a possible ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) or pancreatic necrosis. Troponin levels have peaked, so there is no need to follow the curve. Further plans will be as per the resident's note. The patient remains critically ill with severe pancreatitis and ARDS but is off pressors, able to wean down FiO2 and PEEP in moderate range, and has improving renal function.

   Assessment and Plan
   Patient is a 63 year old male with history of coronary artery disease
   status-post CABG in [**4-/2182**], presents with hypotension, bradycardia,
   epigastric pain, found severe pancreatitis with ARDS and persistent
   pressor requirement, with improved respiratory status, and renal
   function today, weaned off of pressors.
   # Respiratory failure: Hypoxemic respiratory failure and now ARDS.
   Intubated in setting of respiratory distress, also given need for
   aggressive IVF resuscitation. Patient was on paralytics for about 24
   hours to facilitate tolerance of AC mode and lessen resistance.
   Currently he now meets ARDS criteria in setting of pancreatitis and
   possible aspiration.. Suspect that in setting of RV dysfunction noted
   on transthoracic echo (likely from ARDS and positive-pressure
   ventilation, and catecholamines from ARDS/pancreatitis), any movement
   will decrease pre-load/venous return leading to hypotension with
   preferential vasocontrction and resultant transient hypoxia.
   - At goal 6cc/kg ARDSnet ventilation protocol, continue current TV and
   rate settings, will aim to wean FiO2 down to 40%, then consider weaning
   down PEEP.
   - Later today, if off pressors for >12 hrs and stable, will diuresis
   down to CVP <5 to help fluid status
   - Continue vancomycin and meropenem, added ciprofloxacin on [**11-12**] to
   extend coverage against gram negative rods for question of possible VAP
   or resistance organisms (stopped flagyl as  c. difficile negative)
   - Continue sedation with fentanyl and versed
did not tolerate attempts
   to wean sedation overnight as was overbreathing vent and appeared
   uncomfortable.
   .
   # Metabolic acidosis: Much improved overnight as renal function
   improves and ventilatory settings optimized. Suspect this was mainly
   secondary to acute renal failure.
   - Appreciate renal assistance, now appears that renal function
   improving and his acidosis will hopefully continue to improve as well.
   Bicarbonate drip will be consideration should acidosis worsen.
   # Pancreatitis: Patient with severe, acute pancreatitis. Based on
   gallstones seen on CT from OSH (per surgery
s evaluation of this
   imaging), and based on improvement in LFT
s and CBD, story is most
   consistent with gallstone pancreatitis. No history of EtOH use or
   elevated triglycerides. Currently appears that patient has SIRS related
   to his pancreatitis given his persistent hypotension. Intubated for
   hypoxia, had initial bradycardia and hypotension which resolved w/IVF.
   Greatly appreciate surgery and ERCP recommendations and assistance. No
   change in abdominal examination.
   - Patient is status-post > 11 liters of IVF
had held off on further
   fluid resuscitation for hypotension given concerns about oxygenation
   and worsening of abdominal compartment syndrome in setting of poor
   urine output. Given that his bladder pressure remains relatively low
   (11, as compared to 30
s) and he has significant (likely post-ATN)
   auto-diuresis, will aim to wean pressors and bolus with fluids as long
   as respiratory status is stable.
   - Per surgery, no need for repeat imaging at this time, as this would
   have risk of further dye exposure in setting of resolving ARF, and
   already on appropriate antibiotics (and HD stable, so surgical
   intervention not desired)
   - ERCP team aware of patients.
   - Treat w/broad spectrum Abx: Vanc/meropenam (day 1=[**11-10**]), started
   cipro yesterday.
   - Continuing to trend [**Doctor First Name **]/lipase, HCT, WBCs, calcium, (lactate has been
   normal)
   - Triglycerides were within normal limits
   - Sedation to fentanyl/versed
   - Appreciate surgical assistance.
   - Insulin gtt for hyperglycemia
   # Hypotension: Now off pressors! Hypotension with movement as noted
   above likely secondary to decreased venous return and forward flow with
   movement. Overall hypotension most likely secondary to significant
   third spacing of fluids in abdomen from pancreatitis, leading to
   hypovolemia, as well as SIRS from his pancreatitis. No new clear wall
   motion abnormalities on transthoracic echocardiogram. Also in setting
   of post-ATN diuresis and new diarrhea and fevers with insensible
   losses. Do not suspect sepsis from infection as pressor need
   decreasing.
   - Will bolus with IVF if needed in lieu of re-starting pressors.
   - Cardiac enzymes have peaked, no need to continue following unless
   suspect new event
   - Blood, urine, sputum cultures pending, as noted above.

   instead some low levels of demand ischemia secondary to hypotension and
   stress of infection/SIRS/pancreatitis with circulating catecholamies.
   Patient noted to have new TWI in V1, V2, with <1 mm of STE in inferior
   leads- STE noted on prior EKGs from [**4-21**]. Patient does have h/o recent
   4vCABG in 6/[**2181**]. At this time, risks continue to outweigh benefits for
   anticoagulation given concern of hemorrhagic transformation/necrosis.

   case, felt current EKG was not significantly different from old, STE
   could be ventricular aneurismal in nature. No other recommendations for
   change in management, as management of his pancreatitis was felt to be

   - Transthoracic echo today as noted above, suspect depressed RV

   # ARF: Marked improvement to 1.6 today. Suspected ATN secondary to

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 63-year-old male with a history of coronary artery disease, status-post CABG, who presented with hypotension, bradycardia, and epigastric pain. He was diagnosed with severe pancreatitis, acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and persistent pressor requirement. The patient has been intubated and placed on mechanical ventilation. His respiratory status has improved, and he has been weaned off the ventilator. He remains on non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV). The patient's renal function has also improved, and he is no longer requiring renal assistance. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is at risk of respiratory failure due to his ARDS and possible aspiration. The ARDS is causing severe lung injury, leading to hypoxemic respiratory failure. The patient's oxygenation status needs to be closely monitored, and appropriate ventilatory support should be provided.
2. Metabolic Acidosis: The patient had metabolic acidosis, likely secondary to acute renal failure. His renal function has improved, and his acidosis should continue to improve as well. However, close monitoring of his acid-base balance is necessary, and bicarbonate drip may be considered if acidosis worsens.
3. Pancreatitis: The patient has severe acute pancreatitis, likely caused by gallstones. This diagnosis is supported by his imaging findings and improvement in liver function tests (LFTs) and

3. Hypotension: The patient's persistent hypotension could be due to third spacing of fluids in the abdomen from pancreatitis, hypovolemia, or decreased venous return.

- The patient has been on a Lasix drip for diuresis and has remained off pressors.

- The patient is currently receiving various medications such as furosemide, insulin, midazolam, fentanyl, aspirin, chlorhexidine rinses, heparin, albuterol inhaler, pantoprazole, and atrovent inhaler.

- The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a set tidal volume (Vt) of 450 mL, respiratory rate (RR) set at 30 breaths per minute, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 12 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%.
- The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC), creatinine, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), lactate, and troponin levels, as well as elevated glucose and amylase levels. The platelet count and hematocrit (Hct) are within normal range.

- The patient's code status is full code, and the disposition is not mentioned.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's conditions include worsening respiratory distress, sepsis due to infection, acute kidney injury, cardiac arrhythmias, and further deterioration of organ function.
